questions.text: A 2200-g (4-lb 14-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 37-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows that he is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference and at the 10th percentile for length. He has a small jaw, small eyes, and low-set ears. There is a keyhole-shaped defect in the iris of the left eye. He has seven fingers on each hand. There is an opening in the roof of the mouth extending into the soft and hard palate bilaterally. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. The heels are prominent, with convex-shaped deformity of the plantar surface of the feet. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cri-du-chat syndrome is a rare condition caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. The most characteristic feature of the resulting disorder is cat-like, high-pitched crying. Microcephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, moon facies, widely spaced eyes), and congenital heart defects can also be detected at birth, while intellectual disabilities become evident as the child grows. Although this patient has microcephaly, dysmorphic facial features, and likely congenital heart defect, his symptoms cannot be explained by cri-du-chat syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder that primarily manifests in males with intellectual disability, increased height and head circumference, prominent ears, and large testes, which manifest most clearly during adolescence. The anomalies described in this infant are not consistent with a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common chromosomal disorder seen in live births. Infants with trisomy 21 are usually diagnosed based on a combination of classic clinical features, including brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, small mouth, flattened nose), a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal toe. Since the single palmar crease and sandal toe are absent in this infant, and a cleft lip and palate are atypical in trisomy 21, this diagnosis is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is the second most common chromosomal disorder after trisomy 21. Characteristic features include clenched fists with flexion contractures of the fingers, rocker-bottom feet, a prominent occiput, and visceral malformations (e.g., horseshoe kidneys). Further features may include low-set ears, micrognathia, and a cleft lip and palate. Although this infant has some features that are consistent with trisomy 18, his normal head shape, absence of finger contractures, and presence of polydactyly suggest a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Infants with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) typically have dysmorphic facial features, including a thin upper lip, a hypoplastic or absent philtrum, epicanthus, and hypertelorism. Heart defects, renal anomalies, and skeletal malformations (e.g., joint contractures, limb dislocations) can also occur. This patient's rocker-bottom feet, cleft lip/palate, and eye anomalies would not be seen in FAS.

F) CORRECT:

Low birth weight, microcephaly (head circumference < 3rd percentile), coloboma, polydactyly, cleft lip and palate, and rocker-bottom feet (convex foot deformity with prominent heel) are strongly suggestive of trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). Features in addition to those seen in this newborn include holoprosencephaly, microphthalmia, low-set, malformed ears, congenital heart defects (particularly ventricular septal defect), aplasia cutis congenita, omphalocele, polycystic kidney disease, and capillary hemangioma.

Only supportive treatment is available for infants with Patau syndrome and the prognosis is usually very poor (only 5% of infants survive past 6 months of age), with survival being determined by the extent of microcephaly and visceral malformations.

G) INCORRECT:

Williams syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 7. Affected children commonly show characteristic facial features (narrow midface, wide forehead, flattened nose), cardiovascular malformations (e.g., supravalvular aortic stenosis), and intellectual disabilities. This patient has a cleft lip and palate, eye anomalies, and skeletal malformations, which do not occur in children with Williams syndrome.
questions.hint: This newborn's 1st-trimester screening likely would have shown decreased PAPP-A, decreased beta-HCG, and increased nuchal translucency, while 2nd-trimester screening (quad screen test) probably would have been normal.

questions.text: A 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 36-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Apgar scores are 7 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference and 15th percentile for length. Examination shows a prominent posterior part of the head. The ears are low-set and the jaw is small and retracted. The fists are clenched, with overlapping second and third fingers. The calcaneal bones are prominent and the plantar surface of the foot shows a convex deformity. Abdominal examination shows an omphalocele. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) is characterized by congenital cardiac malformations, particularly ventricular septal defects. Edwards syndrome is the second most common autosomal trisomy found in live births. The prognosis for patients with Edwards syndrome is poor, with the majority dying in utero and only 5â€“10% surviving past 12 months of age.

Ventricular septal defects are also associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Down syndrome (trisomy 21).

B) INCORRECT:

Ebstein anomaly is a congenital heart defect characterized by malformed and displaced tricuspid valve leaflets. Ebstein anomaly is often associated with other cardiac malformations such as patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defects. It is generally not inherited, instead arises from sporadic mutations that are not associated with other congenital diseases. Prenatal lithium exposure is also thought to be associated with Ebstein anomaly.

C) INCORRECT:

Macroorchidism is seen in fragile X syndrome. While patients with fragile X may also have facial abnormalities, they usually have long facies with a large jaw, large ears, and a larger than normal head circumference, not microcephaly. Also, macroorchidism in patients with fragile X syndrome does not become apparent until puberty. It would therefore not be expected in this newborn. Fragile X is the second most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after Down syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma can be associated with neurofibromatosis type I, multiple endocrine neoplasia II syndrome, and von Hippel-Lindau disease, none of which are associated with the physical malformations seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Holoprosencephaly is commonly seen in Patau syndrome (trisomy 13). While Patau syndrome may also manifest with microcephaly, organ malformations (like omphalocele and congenital heart defects), rocker-bottom feet (convex deformity of the plantar surface of the foot), and low-set ears, it does not manifest in a prominent occiput or clenched fists with overlapping fingers (Patau syndrome usually manifests with polydactyly). Furthermore, Patau syndrome is characterized by severe midline defects, such as cleft lip and palate, that help differentiate it from other trisomy diseases.

F) INCORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). While Down syndrome may also manifest with low-set ears and organ malformations such as omphalocele, it is not associated with a prominent occiput, microcephaly, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet). Instead, Down syndrome is associated with upslanting palpebral fissures, a broad/flat nasal bridge, and hypertelorism.
questions.hint: Prominent occiput, microcephaly, low-set ears, clenched fists with flexion contractures, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet) are all characteristic of Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18).

questions.text: A 2720-g (6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores are 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, and pointy low-set ears.  The fists are clenched with fingers tightly flexed. The index finger overlaps the third finger and the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. The nipples are widely spaced and the feet have prominent heels and convex, rounded soles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is a genetic syndrome characterized by certain congenital anomalies that are also present in this patient, including low-set ears, flexed fingers, and signs of a congenital cardiac defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of ventricular septal defect). However, other key features of trisomy 13 would also be expected, such as cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and polydactyly.

Second-trimester quadruple screening test for Patau syndrome would show normal levels of free estriol, AFP, Inhibin A, and Î²-HCG

B) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common chromosomal disorder seen in live births. Infants with trisomy 21 are usually diagnosed based on a combination of classic clinical features including brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, protuberant tongue, flattened nasal bridge, hypertelorism), a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal gap deformity. This child does exhibit some features of Down syndrome, e.g., flattened nasal bridge and upward slanting eyes with small palpebral fissures, but the absence of all other typical features makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.

Second-trimester quadruple screening test for Down syndrome would show â†“ free estriol, â†“ AFP, â†‘ Inhibin A, and â†‘ Î²-HCG.

C) INCORRECT:

Maternal alcohol intake during pregnancy is the most common cause of teratogenic damage in children. It manifests in a spectrum of features, which are collectively referred to as fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). This child does present with a few common features of FAS, such as narrow palpebral fissures, micrognathia, and evidence of a congenital cardiac anomaly. However, she lacks most other typical features, such as a hypoplastic philtrum, down-slanting and widely spaced palpebral fissures, and a narrow forehead. Moreover, this patient's rocker-bottom feet, low-set ears, clenched fists, and prominent occiput would not be seen in FAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Monosomy X (45,XO) is the karyotype associated with Turner syndrome, which is a common disorder of sex development in females. However, apart from the widely spaced nipples, there are no features typical for Turner syndrome, e.g., lymphedema of the limbs, high arched palate, and webbed neck, present in this child.

E) INCORRECT:

This genotype is associated with Cri-du-chat syndrome. The most characteristic feature of the resulting disorder is cat-like, high-pitched crying, which is not present in this child. Other features that this child has in common with Cri-du-chat syndrome are a likely congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of VSD) and low birth weight. However, the girl is lacking the typical facial anomalies (e.g., epicanthus, moon facies, widely spaced eyes) and microcephaly.

F) INCORRECT:

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder. This condition is characterized by varying degrees of intellectual disability, increased height and head circumference, and prominent ears. This female patient is very unlikely to have fragile X syndrome because it is most commonly symptomatic in males. Moreover, the physical features typically manifest most clearly during adolescence and are rarely noticeable at birth. The anomalies described in this infant, the age, and the gender are all not consistent with a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome.

G) CORRECT:

This infant's features are consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). Classic features include a characteristic craniofacial morphology (micrognathia, prominent occiput, and pointy, low-set ears), clenched fists with flexion contractures of the fingers, and rocker-bottom feet (convex foot deformity with prominent heel). The infant also presents with other features that are commonly associated with the syndrome, such as a congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of ventricular septal defect), and low birth weight (suggestive of intrauterine growth restriction).

The prognosis for trisomy 18 is poor, with only up to 10% of infants surviving past 12 months of age.
questions.hint: A second-trimester quadruple screening test would have shown â†“ free estriol, â†“ AFP, â†” inhibin A, and â†“ Î²-HCG.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14-weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Routine first trimester screening shows increased nuchal translucency, decreased Î²-hCG concentration, and decreased levels of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A. Amniocentesis shows trisomy of chromosome 13. This fetus is at increased risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic gliomas are associated with Neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease). Ocular disorders associated with Trisomy 13 include coloboma and ocular hypotelorism.

B) CORRECT:

Cutis aplasia is characteristic of trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). Other externally visible clinical features include microcephaly, cleft lip and cleft palate, microphthalmia, polydactyly, and rocker-bottom feet. Patients have approximately an 80% risk of having congenital heart defects (particularly ventricular septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus) and often visceral and genital anomalies (especially the kidneys and ureter).

First trimester screening for Trisomy 13 shows increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound, as well as serum levels of decreased Î²-hCG concentration and significantly decreased levels of PAPP-A. Only 5% of infants with trisomy 13 survive past 6 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased risk of duodenal atresia is seen in âˆ¼ 30% patients with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). While Down syndrome would also show increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound and decreased levels of PAPP-A, the Î²-hCG concentration would be elevated. While trisomy 13 can cause visceral and genital anomalies, especially of the kidneys and ureter, it is not typically associated with malformations of the gastrointestinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystic hygromas are associated with Turner syndrome (monosomy X). While Trisomy 13 can present with vascular tumors of the skin, it is most often associated with external capillary hemangiomas as opposed to internal cavernous lymphangiomas (cystic hygroma).

E) INCORRECT:

Prominent occiput is characteristic of trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome). While first trimester screening tests would also show nuchal translucency on ultrasound, decreased Î²-hCG, and decreased PAPP-A, trisomy 18 additionally causes a decrease in free estriol, alpha fetoprotein, and inhibin A levels, unlike in this patient. Additional features of Trisomy 18 include low-set ears, micrognathia, and cleft lip and cleft palate.
questions.hint: Trisomy 13 is the karyotype of Patau syndrome.

questions.text: A 2200-g (4-lbs 13-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 37-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman. The newborn is at the 10th percentile for length, 14th percentile for weight, and 3rd percentile for head circumference. Examination shows â€œpunched-outâ€ skin lesions on the scalp, cleft lip, and a small chin. The patient's feet have a convex plantar surface. Auscultation shows a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Some of her intestines protrude through the umbilicus, covered by a thin membranous sac. An MRI of the brain shows a single ventricle and fusion of the basal ganglia. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Polydactyly of the hands and sometimes feet (typically hexadactyly) is a characteristic finding in children with trisomy 13. Features in addition to those seen in this newborn include microphthalmia/anophthalmia, coloboma, low-set, malformed ears, polycystic kidney disease, and capillary hemangiomata. Approximately 80% of affected children have a congenital heart defect, as suspected in this newborn, whose heart murmur is consistent with a ventricular septal defect. Only supportive treatment is available for infants with trisomy 13, and the prognosis is usually very poor (only 11% of infants survive past 12 months of age).

B) INCORRECT:

A webbed neck is a characteristic finding in individuals with Turner syndrome. Although low birth weight and heart murmurs can also be present in newborns with Turner syndrome, features such as microcephaly, cutis aplasia, cleft lip, rocker-bottom feet, omphalocele, and holoprosencephaly are not associated with this condition. Moreover, Turner syndrome typically manifests with lymphedema of the hands and feet, nail dysplasia, and a high-arched palate, none of which are seen here. This newborn's presentation is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with a webbed neck.

C) INCORRECT:

High-pitched crying is a characteristic finding in individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome, which is caused by a microdeletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. Although a small chin, cleft lip, microcephaly, and congenital heart defects may be present in newborns with cri-du-chat syndrome, features such as aplasia cutis, rocker-bottom feet, and holoprosencephaly are suggestive of a different diagnosis. Moreover, cri-du-chat syndrome typically manifests with dysmorphic facial features such as moon facies, widely spaced eyes, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, and downward-slanting palpebral fissures, none of which are seen here. This newborn's presentation is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with high-pitched crying.

D) INCORRECT:

Clenched fists with overlapping fingers (2nd and 5th fingers overlap 3rd and 4th fingers, respectively) are a characteristic finding in children with trisomy 18. Although some of the features seen in this newborn can also be present in trisomy 18 (e.g., microcephaly, cleft lip, rocker-bottom feet, omphalocele, heart murmur), the presence of cutis aplasia and holoprosencephaly is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with overlapping fingers.

E) INCORRECT:

A hypoplastic philtrum is a characteristic finding in individuals with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). Although some of the features seen in this newborn can also be present in FAS (e.g., low birth weight, microcephaly, heart murmur, holoprosencephaly), findings such as cutis aplasia, cleft lip, rocker-bottom feet, and omphalocele are not associated with this diagnosis. Moreover, FAS typically manifests with down-slanting, short palpebral fissures, and hypertelorism, none of which are seen in this newborn. Her presentation is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with a hypoplastic philtrum.
questions.hint: Aplasia cutis (â€œpunched-outâ€ scalp lesions), cleft lip, holoprosencephaly on MRI, and findings indicative of congenital heart disease (holosystolic murmur), in addition to low birth weight, microcephaly, small chin, rocker-bottom feet (convex deformity with prominent heels), and omphalocele, are all highly suggestive of trisomy 13.

questions.text:
A 5-hour-old female infant is being evaluated for a murmur. She was born at a gestational age of 37 weeks to a 37-year-old woman, who has one other living biological child. The mother declined all testing during pregnancy. The infantâ€™s birth weight was 2875 grams.
On examination, the infant is alert and in no acute respiratory distress. She has a prominent occiput and low-set, posteriorly rotated ears (figure 1). Cardiac examination reveals a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Her hands and feet are shown in the figures.
What is the most likely underlying genetic diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common autosomal trisomy disorder, followed by trisomies 13 and 18, which affect 1 in 5000 and 3 in 10,000 newborns, respectively. This patient most likely has trisomy 18, which is characterized by a prominent occiput; low-set, posteriorly rotated ears; clenched fists with overlapping fingers; and rocker-bottom feet. Trisomy 18 is often associated with congenital heart defects.

Key learning point: The genetic syndrome characterized by a prominent occiput, low-set ears that are posteriorly rotated, congenital heart disease, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet is trisomy 18.

B) INCORRECT:

Infants with trisomy 13 are also dysmorphic and typically exhibit midline facial defects (orofacial clefting, holoprosencephaly), postaxial polydactyly, congenital talipes equinovarus, and aplasia cutis congenita.

C) INCORRECT:

Features of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DiGeorge or velocardiofacial syndrome) include conotruncal cardiac anomalies, hypoplastic thymus, and hypocalcemia. Facial features include low-set posteriorly rotated ears, ocular hypertelorism, and a bulbous nose tip. A cleft palate is also common.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants with Turner syndrome have a webbed neck with a low hairline, widespread nipples, micrognathia, and lymphedema of the hands and feet. The karyotype is typically 45,X.

E) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 is characterized by up-slanting palpebral fissures, epicanthic folds, a flat nasal bridge, a single palmar crease, and a wide space between the first and second toes. Infants with trisomy 21 are at risk for congenital heart defects, most commonly atrioventricular canal defects.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl who is new to your clinic presents for well-child care. Her parents note that while she was growing up, she received physical therapy for hypotonia and gross-motor developmental delay. She has documented learning disabilities and has also had difficulty paying attention in school.
Her vital signs are normal. She is at the 85th percentile for height and the 75th percentile for weight. Breast development and pubic hair are consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 3, but she has not yet reached menarche. Physical examination is remarkable only for epicanthal folds and joint hyperextensibility.
Which one of the following genetic disorders is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by tall stature, but delayed menarche and dysmorphic features, such as epicanthal folds, are not typical. Furthermore, patients with this syndrome tend to present much earlier than this patient did, because of the high risk for hypoglycemia in infancy. Physical findings in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome may include macroglossia and limb hypertrophy; affected patients may also be born with omphalocele. Although most individuals with this syndrome show rapid growth in early childhood, height typically remains at the upper range of normal; the growth rate usually slows around 7 to 8 years of age. Because this syndrome is associated with an increased risk for tumors, including Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma, frequent screening is recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

The developmental and behavioral features seen in triple X syndrome may also be seen in fragile X syndrome. Although fragile X syndrome can cause primary ovarian insufficiency with early menopause, it is not associated with menstrual irregularities.

C) CORRECT:

Triple X syndrome (also known as trisomy X or 47,XXX syndrome) is the most common female chromosomal abnormality, occurring in 1 in 1000 female births. However, it is diagnosed in only about 10% of cases because most patients are asymptomatic or only mildly affected. Many cases are diagnosed prenatally by amniocentesis or chorionic villi sampling, but these patients should still undergo karyotyping after delivery to evaluate for the concomitant presence of 45,X mosaicism.

There is considerable variability in the phenotypic expression of triple X syndrome. Physical features may include tall stature, epicanthal folds, hypotonia, joint hyperextensibility, clinodactyly, hypertelorism, and pes planus. In addition, affected girls may present with late menarche and menstrual irregularities; some also have fertility problems. For many individuals with triple X syndrome, the most notable symptoms are developmental and psychological problems, including diminished gross-motor and language skills. Affected patients may also have lower IQs in both verbal and nonverbal domains, and they are at increased risk for attention-deficit and anxiety disorders.

Individuals with triple X syndrome are at increased risk for seizures, renal and genitourinary abnormalities (unilateral renal agenesis, renal dysplasia, and ovarian malformations), congenital heart defects (atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and aortic coarctation), and primary ovarian insufficiency.

Key learning point: The chromosomal anomaly that is most likely to cause a girl with minimal dysmorphic features to have tall stature, hypotonia, learning disabilities, and menstrual irregularities is triple X syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is caused by a defect in fibrillin, a protein involved in building connective tissue. Patients with this syndrome are tall in stature with long arms, legs, and fingers. They may suffer from ocular lens dislocation and cardiovascular complications, including aortic root dilation and life-threatening aortic dissection. Delayed menarche and cognitive deficits are not associated with Marfan syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Turner syndrome has some similar features to those seen in triple X syndrome, including renal and genitourinary anomalies and left-sided congenital heart defects (such as bicuspid aortic valves, aortic stenosis, and aortic coarctation). However, patients with Turner syndrome frequently have short stature as a predominant feature rather than tall stature.

questions.text:
A female infant is born via precipitous vaginal delivery to a 27-year-old woman with limited prenatal care who reports being at 39 weeksâ€™ gestation. The infant weighs 1.9 kg at birth and is active and vigorous with good color and tone; however, she appears to be in respiratory distress. Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation is initiated.
The infant has a temperature of 37.1Â°C, a heart rate of 145 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 75 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% at 2 minutes of life while receiving continuous positive airway pressure with a positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cm of water and a 21% fraction of inspired oxygen.
On examination, the infant is crying, vigorous, and pink but in mild distress. She is found to have a prominent occiput, hypertelorism, overlapping fingers, and a cleft lip. She exhibits tachypnea and moderate work of breathing, with nasal flaring and subcostal retractions. Auscultation reveals coarse lung sounds, and a 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. Peripheral pulses are 2+, and there is no brachiofemoral delay.
What is the most likely cardiac anomaly in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve stenosis typically produces a high-pitched, systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border.

B) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect itself does not cause a murmur; however, increased blood flow across the pulmonary valve (related to shunting at the atrial level) could lead to a fixed, widely split S2 and a soft systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral pulmonary stenosis produces a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and radiates to the back and axilla.

D) CORRECT:

This infant has dysmorphic features characteristic of trisomy 18 and a murmur on examination, consistent with a ventricular septal defect.

Ventricular septal defects account for up to 40% of all congenital heart disease and are the most common anomaly associated with trisomy 18. The amount of blood flow across the defect is determined by the defectâ€™s overall size and by the resistance between the pulmonary and systemic circulations. As pulmonary vascular resistance falls after birth, the amount of left-to-right shunting increases, which can lead to signs and symptoms of excessive pulmonary blood flow, such as respiratory distress, poor feeding, failure to thrive, and enlargement of the left-sided cardiac chambers. The classic auscultation finding on physical examination is a holosystolic or pansystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border. The size of the defect dictates the intensity of the murmur: smaller defects produce harsher murmurs, and larger defects produce less-intense murmurs. Over time, if a large defect causes the left heart to enlarge, a diastolic rumble may be heard at the apex because of increased blood flow across the mitral valve.

Trisomy 18 has variable phenotypes that can include distinct craniofacial and skeletal malformations, including microcephaly, prominent occiput, cleft lip and palate, micrognathia, ocular malformations, rocker-bottom feet, overlapping fingers, and clenched hands. Most patients with trisomy 18 also have intrauterine growth restriction, genital malformations (such as cryptorchidism), and abdominal wall and kidney defects. Congenital heart defects occur frequently, with the most common being ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, and abnormalities of the valves (thickening or dysplasia of the valve leaflets).

Atrial septal defects, aortic valve stenosis, pulmonary valve stenosis, and peripheral pulmonary stenosis do not commonly occur in trisomy 18, and their associated murmurs are heard best in different locations on the chest and have distinct qualities.

Key learning point: The most likely cardiac anomaly in an infant who has features of trisomy 18 and a harsh holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border is a ventricular septal defect.

E) INCORRECT:

The murmur associated with pulmonary valve stenosis is typically a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

questions.text: You are caring for a female newborn, weighing 2720 g, delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores are 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. On examination in the delivery room, the newborn has micrognathia, a prominent occiput with a flattened nasal bridge, and pointy low-set ears. The eyes are upward slanting with small palpebral fissures. The fists are clenched with tightly flexed fingers; the index finger overlaps the third finger, and the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. The nipples are widely spaced, and the feet have prominent heels and convex, rounded soles. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monosomy X (45,XO) is the karyotype associated with Turner syndrome, which is a common disorder of sex development in females. However, apart from the widely spaced nipples, there are no features typical for Turner syndrome, e.g., lymphedema of the limbs, high arched palate, and webbed neck, present in this child.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal alcohol intake during pregnancy is the most common cause of teratogenic damage in children. It manifests in a spectrum of features, which are collectively referred to as fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). This child does present with a few common features of FAS, such as narrow palpebral fissures, micrognathia, and evidence of a congenital cardiac anomaly. However, she lacks most other typical features, such as a hypoplastic philtrum, down-slanting and widely spaced palpebral fissures, and a narrow forehead. Moreover, this patient's rocker-bottom feet, low-set ears, clenched fists, and prominent occiput would not be seen in FAS.

C) CORRECT:

This infant's features are consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). Classic features include a characteristic craniofacial morphology (micrognathia, prominent occiput, and pointy, low-set ears), clenched fists with flexion contractures of the fingers, and rocker-bottom feet (convex foot deformity with prominent heel). The infant also presents with other features that are commonly associated with the syndrome, such as a congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of ventricular septal defect), and low birth weight (suggestive of intrauterine growth restriction).

The prognosis for trisomy 18 is poor, with only up to 10% of infants surviving past 12 months of age.

Key learning point: Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) presents with micrognathia, prominent occiput, low-set ears, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart defects.

D) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is a genetic syndrome characterized by certain congenital anomalies that are also present in this patient, including low-set ears, flexed fingers, and signs of a congenital cardiac defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of ventricular septal defect). However, other key features of trisomy 13 would also be expected, such as cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and polydactyly.

Second-trimester quadruple screening test for Patau syndrome would show normal levels of free estriol, AFP, Inhibin A, and Î²-HCG

E) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common chromosomal disorder seen in live births. Infants with trisomy 21 are usually diagnosed based on a combination of classic clinical features including brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, protuberant tongue, flattened nasal bridge, hypertelorism), a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal gap deformity. This child does exhibit some features of Down syndrome, e.g., flattened nasal bridge and upward slanting eyes with small palpebral fissures, but the absence of all other typical features makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.

Second-trimester quadruple screening test for Down syndrome would show â†“ free estriol, â†“ AFP, â†‘ Inhibin A, and â†‘ Î²-HCG.
questions.hint: A second-trimester quadruple screening test would have shown â†“ free estriol, â†“ AFP, â†” inhibin A, and â†“ Î²-HCG.

questions.text: You are caring for a female newborn, delivered at term, weighing 2200 g to a 37-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The newborn's length is at the 10th percentile, weight at the 14th percentile, and head circumference at the 3rd percentile. On examination, there are â€œpunched-outâ€ skin lesions on the scalp, a cleft lip, and micrognathia. The feet have a convex plantar surface. Auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. Some intestines are protruding through the umbilicus, covered by a thin membranous sac. MRI of the brain shows a single ventricle and fusion of the basal ganglia. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clenched fists with overlapping fingers (2nd and 5th fingers overlap 3rd and 4th fingers, respectively) are a characteristic finding in children with trisomy 18. Although some of the features seen in this newborn can also be present in trisomy 18 (e.g., microcephaly, cleft lip, rocker-bottom feet, omphalocele, heart murmur), the presence of cutis aplasia and holoprosencephaly is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with overlapping fingers.

B) INCORRECT:

High-pitched crying is a characteristic finding in individuals with cri-du-chat syndrome, which is caused by a microdeletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. Although a small chin, cleft lip, microcephaly, and congenital heart defects may be present in newborns with cri-du-chat syndrome, features such as aplasia cutis, rocker-bottom feet, and holoprosencephaly are suggestive of a different diagnosis. Moreover, cri-du-chat syndrome typically manifests with dysmorphic facial features such as moon facies, widely spaced eyes, epicanthal folds, broad nasal bridge, and downward-slanting palpebral fissures, none of which are seen here. This newborn's presentation is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with high-pitched crying.

C) CORRECT:

Polydactyly of the hands and sometimes feet (typically hexadactyly) is a characteristic finding in children with trisomy 13. Features in addition to those seen in this newborn include microphthalmia/anophthalmia, coloboma, low-set, malformed ears, polycystic kidney disease, and capillary hemangiomata. Approximately 80% of affected children have a congenital heart defect, as suspected in this newborn, whose heart murmur is consistent with a ventricular septal defect. Only supportive treatment is available for infants with trisomy 13, and the prognosis is usually very poor (only 11% of infants survive past 12 months of age).

Key learning point: Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is characterized by polydactyly, midline facial defects, holoprosencephaly, cutis aplasia, congenital heart defects, and poor prognosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A hypoplastic philtrum is a characteristic finding in individuals with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). Although some of the features seen in this newborn can also be present in FAS (e.g., low birth weight, microcephaly, heart murmur, holoprosencephaly), findings such as cutis aplasia, cleft lip, rocker-bottom feet, and omphalocele are not associated with this diagnosis. Moreover, FAS typically manifests with down-slanting, short palpebral fissures, and hypertelorism, none of which are seen in this newborn. Her presentation is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with a hypoplastic philtrum.

E) INCORRECT:

A webbed neck is a characteristic finding in individuals with Turner syndrome. Although low birth weight and heart murmurs can also be present in newborns with Turner syndrome, features such as microcephaly, cutis aplasia, cleft lip, rocker-bottom feet, omphalocele, and holoprosencephaly are not associated with this condition. Moreover, Turner syndrome typically manifests with lymphedema of the hands and feet, nail dysplasia, and a high-arched palate, none of which are seen here. This newborn's presentation is more consistent with trisomy 13, which is not associated with a webbed neck.
questions.hint: Aplasia cutis (â€œpunched-outâ€ scalp lesions), cleft lip, holoprosencephaly on MRI, and findings indicative of congenital heart disease (holosystolic murmur), in addition to low birth weight, microcephaly, small chin, rocker-bottom feet (convex deformity with prominent heels), and omphalocele, are all highly suggestive of trisomy 13.

questions.text: You are caring for a newborn boy weighing 1900 g who is delivered at term to a 36-year-old primigravid woman. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Apgar scores are 7 at 1 minute and 7 at 5 minutes. He is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference and 15th percentile for length. On examination, he has a prominent posterior skull, low-set ears, and a small, retracted jaw. His fists are clenched with overlapping second and third fingers. The calcaneal bones are prominent, and the plantar surface of the foot has a convex deformity. Abdominal examination reveals an omphalocele. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) is characterized by congenital cardiac malformations, particularly ventricular septal defects. Edwards syndrome is the second most common autosomal trisomy found in live births. The prognosis for patients with Edwards syndrome is poor, with the majority dying in utero and only 5â€“10% surviving past 12 months of age.

Ventricular septal defects are also associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Down syndrome (trisomy 21).

Key learning point: Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) is commonly associated with ventricular septal defects and multiple congenital anomalies, including micrognathia, clenched fists, and rocker-bottom feet.

B) INCORRECT:

Aplasia cutis congenita of the scalp is commonly seen in Patau syndrome (trisomy 13), not with trisomy 18. While Patau syndrome may also manifest with microcephaly, organ malformations (like omphalocele and congenital heart defects), rocker-bottom feet (convex deformity of the plantar surface of the foot), and low-set ears, it does not manifest in a prominent occiput or clenched fists with overlapping fingers (Patau syndrome usually manifests with polydactyly). Furthermore, Patau syndrome is characterized by severe midline defects, such as cleft lip and palate, that help differentiate it from other trisomy diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Hirschsprung disease is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). While Down syndrome may also manifest with low-set ears and organ malformations such as omphalocele, it is not associated with a prominent occiput, microcephaly, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet). Instead, Down syndrome is associated with upslanting palpebral fissures, a broad/flat nasal bridge, and hypertelorism.

D) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma can be associated with neurofibromatosis type I, multiple endocrine neoplasia II syndrome, and von Hippel-Lindau disease, none of which are associated with the physical malformations seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Macroorchidism is seen in fragile X syndrome. While patients with fragile X may also have facial abnormalities, they usually have long facies with a large jaw, large ears, and a larger than normal head circumference, not microcephaly. Also, macroorchidism in patients with fragile X syndrome does not become apparent until puberty. It would therefore not be expected in this newborn.
questions.hint: Prominent occiput, microcephaly, low-set ears, clenched fists with flexion contractures, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet) are all characteristic of Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18).

questions.text: A 2720-g (6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Examination in the delivery room shows micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, and pointy low-set ears. The eyes are upward slanting with small palpebral fissures. The fists are clenched with fingers tightly flexed. The index finger overlaps the third finger and the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. The nipples are widely spaced and the feet have prominent heels and convex, rounded soles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This infant's features are consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). Classic features include a characteristic craniofacial morphology (micrognathia, prominent occiput, and pointy, low-set ears), clenched fists with flexion contractures of the fingers, and rocker-bottom feet (convex foot deformity with prominent heel). The infant also presents with other features that are commonly associated with the syndrome, such as a congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of VSD) and low birth weight (suggestive of intrauterine growth retardation).

B) INCORRECT:

Monosomy X (45,XO) is the karyotype associated with Turner syndrome, which is a common disorder of sex development in females. However, apart from the widely spaced nipples, there are no features typical for Turner syndrome, e.g., lymphedema of the limbs, high arched palate, and webbed neck, present in this child. Monosomy Y is not compatible with life.

C) INCORRECT:

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) results from maternal alcohol intake during pregnancy, which is the most common cause of teratogenic damage in children. It manifests in a spectrum of features, and this child does present with a few common features of FAS, such as narrow palpebral fissures, micrognathia, and evidence of a congenital cardiac anomaly. However, she lacks most other typical features, such as a hypoplastic philtrum, down-slanting and widely spaced palpebral fissures, and narrow forehead. Moreover, this patient's rocker-bottom feet, low-set ears, clenched fists, and prominent occiput would not be seen in FAS.

D) INCORRECT:

This genotype is associated with Cri-du-chat syndrome. This patient's likely congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of VSD) and low birth weight are consistent with Cri-du-chat syndrome. However, she does not have the most characteristic feature: a cat-like, high-pitched crying. Additionally, she lacks the typical facial anomalies (e.g., epicanthus, moon facies, widely spaced eyes) and microcephaly.

E) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is a genetic syndrome characterized by certain congenital anomalies that are also present in this child, including low-set ears, flexed fingers, and signs of a congenital cardiac defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of VSD). However, other key features of trisomy 13, such as cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and polydactyly, would also be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common chromosomal disorder seen in live births. Infants with trisomy 21 are usually diagnosed based on a combination of classic clinical features including: brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, protuberant tongue, flattened nasal bridge, hypertelorism), a single transverse palmar crease, and a sandal gap deformity. This child does exhibit some features of Down syndrome, (e.g., flattened nasal bridge, upward slanting eyes with small palpebral fissures, and presence of VSD), but the absence of all other typical features as well as the presence of additional features (micrognathia, rocker-bottom feet) makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.
questions.hint: Second trimester quadruple screening test would have shown â†“ free estriol, â†“ AFP, â†“ Inhibin A, and â†“ Î²-HCG.
